After Pcearro, In which Mrs. M'Aibrom sustained the part of KU’trn, after an absence of fire years, with at least as much tale At as any actress at present ho the London hoards, a Musical Komar ". called The While ¡Aidy, or, The Spirit of jivenei, was produced; the wsrll translated by Mr. Bea/.
LKY, and the greater part of the music by the celebrated
(French composer Boibldiru. it might m supposed from the title, that tire piece is founded upon The Monastery, ;l ** by the Grent Known, and certainly the author of the French copy baa had I oat novel in view, and ha* taken some of his names from it, but the story is so altered in all its essential features, as scarcely to be recognised. We shall not undertake to point out the discrepancies, but enable the reader to discover them by the following brief sketch of (he plot of the pro* f :/< viivj ,,.. Mt» « duct!«« of last night.
. <	| / »aie.au:	^ Julum qf Avenel (Mr. Archer), by drowning (as he he-
***•'***"	lieves) his nephew, Roland Grume (Mr. Horn), son of Walter
of Avenel, claims the castle and domains left by his brother.
»IM From the Hall of Statues that of the White Lady he" Usappear-ed. and the prophecy is, that it will return to its pedestal only when the rignt heir has been discovered. The claim nf Juluin being disputed) the Prince Abbot of Avenel (as he is called) orders that he shall not be installed in his possessions Until the lapse of a certain number of years. Rotund Qrame had been thrown, by an assassin in the pay of Julian, into a river, and saved by a Newfoundland dog, and, after a long absence from the country, returns, and by the greatest good luck imaginable, savra the daughter of Julian from the hands of ruftiaus. He has previously hml a dreatn, in which he was advised to repair to Avene!, and to consult the Whtie Ladu who lives in the fountain, on the subject of his ancestry. He Invokes ber and she appears to him, hut lie obtains no satisfactory information, and enters the castle of Aveuai as a weary traveller asking hospitality, which is granted him byju-Ran, who occupies it. He is provided with a bed in the haunted chamber of the White Lady, and thither he is followed .	'
at midnight by Mary (Miss (/raddon), Julian's daughter, ' whom he had formerly rescued, and who, as is very natural, and indeed quite of course in a drama, has > , fallen desperately in lore with him, and confesses it. at this interview, during which they are encouraged by the voice of the White ¡Mdy, and her visible appearance in the . . wiudow by means of a transparency. Julian having his ' f nephew, the rightful heir, again in his power, employ! an ft* ' •ssasin named (7*/ Lttw (Mr. O. Smith) to stab hioi, and lie would have accomplished his purpose, notwithstanding the presence of the White IjaJy, hut for the timely «rriv*l of Adam , Woodcock (Mr Haklev) , who arrest* the villain’s arm. in the ■> -mean while, the Prince Abbot has obtained from Friar Pkilty, otic of the brotherhood, a confession and proof that Roland Gratae ‘ is the true Lord of the Castle of Avenel, and that he was not , illegitimate, as had been alleged by his uncle. He, followed by an armed traiu from the monastery, reaches the castle just at the moment when his presence was most essential, and there proclaims the right of Roland■ Julian disputes it on the ground that the statue of the White fxidy had not resumed her piacenn to»pedestal, h«t the moment Roland Qrame enters the ball, the figure ittien to rise to i»« place, ¿k»lJ the vassalsacknow
